content.description: Like a wild bore, you must bust up the center of the west-facing slab on the East Colfax formation.  Enjoy moderate climbing until you hit a closely bolted headwall section.  Get a good rest, and like a wild bore, grunt your way up and over the headwall onto a nice ledge!!  From here, find your way up the bolt line to the anchors of this fresh new line!!!
content.location: This line is located on the center of the west side of the East Colfax wall.  Super fun!! It climbs so much better than it may appear, so do get on the Wild Bore Ride!!!

content.description: This was drilled on my 64th birthday (12/27/2013), hence the name.
content.location:
Begin just right of

Speeding Ticket

at a smooth slab.

climbs.name: Warn 'er
climbs.fa: Doug Redosh, Dave Clark Rogers, LP?

content.description:
This is a more-difficult-than-it-looks crack system to the left of

Tweety

.

Start down and left at an obvious crack going up to a nook.  Place pro with long sling(s), and make a slightly precarious traverse (crux) right to gain the obvious crack system.  Continue upwards with face holds and occasionally funky jams to finish in a wider slot.  A directional off the tree to the left (2 x 48" slings) may be nice for the follower.  Use the anchor bolts down and right as for

Tweety

.

FWIW, this felt a bit harder than

Tweety

.
content.protection: A single rack of nuts to a #3 Camalot worked; however, it seemed that there were multiple #1 Camalot sized placements.  The wires that you may use just seem to not quite set in the slicker rock slots.
content.location:
This is down and left of

Tweety

starting perhaps 30 feet left and finishing perhaps 10 feet left.

content.description: This has interesting climbing marred only by some ledges.
content.protection: 7 bolts (plus an optional sling on a horn) to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
50 yards down river from

For the Children

is (for want of a better name) The Warner Brothers Pinnacle, located right on the trail. This is the leftmost route. The top of this pinnacle has three 1/2" bolts that appear to be one terminal for a slackline, possibly across the river.

climbs.name: To the Ends of the Earth

content.description: Climb big holds at a small, left-facing corner, cheating as much right as you want. Easy climbing leads to a steep finish on incut holds.
content.location:
As the name suggests, this is the last climb on the Earth Wall. It is 15 feet right of

Another Earth

. Approach all of these routes by staying close to the wall.

content.description: This is excellent face/slab climbing on good rock leads to the crux at the top. If it seems hard, you are missing the sequence.
content.location: It is the 3rd route from the left. Begin 10 feet off the trail on the talus slope.

content.description:
Located left of

Wild Bore

, we have a slabuless route that show cases two main crux sections! I'll just say there's one crux down low with another just past the mid-point before you pull onto a rest ledge before moving up to the chains! This is a super fun line, and it is great for new leaders as I put in a good deal of tightly spaced bolts through both crux sections! I love this slab and found it to be a worthwhile wall to climb on! I will add some beat photos and some climb pics when I get a chance! Fun line!
content.location:
The line is found on the East Colfax wall just left of the route

Wild Bore

!  It's a slab route to not be missed.  The approach is the same as for East Colfax.  Park at the Primo Wall parking and head downstream to where the current Tyrol is set to access The Armory and all the walls located on the other side of the river.  Once at the Tyrol (before crossing the creek), just look up and right and the slab will come into view.   Enjoy cuz I did!

climbs.name: Speeding Ticket
climbs.fa: Susanna Dent, Hunt Prothro, Greg Hand, 6/10/2013

content.description: Beware on your drive up the canyon or you will understand how this climb was named. Moderate climbing leads to thin moves near the top.
content.protection:
10 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.

A higher 2-bolt anchor has been placed 10 feet higher.
content.location:
Begin just right of

Wild Bore

.

content.description: One For All may be slightly harder (thinner moves) than the routes on either side. At the 4th bolt, angle up and right to the anchors below the big roof. These are all good beginner climbs.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
Begin between

For the Children

and

For the Grandchildren

.

content.description:
It's actually a lot harder.

The 1st pitch climbs the slanting roof above

For the Children

and is about 5.10b.

The 2nd pitch (10+) has a crux above the belay and one just before the anchors. Follow line of bolts on the left side of the final roof. Realize the 10b/c consensus rating is because many people only do the 1st pitch and rate it 10a. The 2nd pitch is harder. As someone indicated, they did it in 1 long pitch, but there will be tremendous rope drag at the top crux.

A 60m rope will make it to the ground on rappel. You probably cannot lower because of abrasion. Because of current river noise, you will not be able to hear the leader. This may change by season. Belaying from the midway anchors, you will not be able to see the leader. Have a plan in advance. The 1st pitch is very good on its own, and you can lower to the ground.
content.protection:
1st pitch - 10 bolts to chains.

2nd pitch - 7 bolts to chains.
content.location:
This is the extension above

For the Children

.

content.description: Hard boulder problem moves lead through the initial bulge. Easy climbing leads to a steep bulge on big holds.
content.location:
Begin 10 feet right of

Earth First

.

climbs.name: I Tawt I Taw A Puddy Tat

content.description:
This has varied climbing on good rock: slabs, mantels, and bulges. It is a little squeezed, perhaps finish on the last move of

Tweety

.
content.protection:
9 bolts (share one with

Sylvester

) to a 2-bolt anchor (either

Tweety

or

Sylvester

).
content.location:
Begin on the trail a few feet right of

Tweety

.

content.description: This is certainly the best easy route in the area. The holds are incredible. I was laughing the whole way. It can be used to access the harder routes for top ropes for beginners. This should be popular.
content.location:
This is the rightmost route on the pinnacle. It is 10 feet right of

Sylvester

.

climbs.name: Hunting Party
climbs.fa: Hunt Prothro, Susanna Dent, Greg Hand, 6/10/2013

content.description: Hunt came out from the east coast to visit his daughter in Boulder, and we had a party. Mount the large boulder and follow bolts straight up on big holds to the crux roof. This has fun moves.
content.location:
Begin 100 feet uphill from

Speeding Ticket

at a level spot in the trail.

content.description: Awkward/slopy holds lead through the initial overhang. Then tackle the steep rock/overhang above(crux).
content.location:
Begin a few feet right of

Earth Mover

at a left-slanting crack through the overhang.

climbs.name: Handy Work
climbs.fa: Hand? Heyliger? Doug Redosh? Dave Clark Rogers? LP?

content.description:
This is an obvious line just to the right of

I Did! I Did!

and comes perilously close to that line.  In fact, it is entirely possible that this is the route used to access the top of this small buttress.  It takes a bit of effort to keep it distinct up near the top, perhaps bumping it to 5.5 or 5.6 if you try to stay off it.

Go up the loose slope.  Climb a crack/dihedral past a bush.  Avoid clipping the bolts. Finish to the top of the buttress.  Downclimb to the anchor bolts down and right.

Note, if it is your route, let me know and I can update the info.
content.protection: A light rack of wires to a #3 Camalot works.
content.location:
This is just right of

I Did! I Did!

.

content.description:
The Good Earth is an improbable looking line that climbs quite well. Begin 20 feet right of

Hunting Part

y following bolts up, then right through the overhang (crux). Then follow the left line of bolts above.
content.location:
We began excavating the area right of

Hunting Party

on Earth Day (4/22/2014). Because of that, we have named this area The Earth Wall. Hence, the naming convention. All of the routes tend to have a common theme. These have hard starts to an easy middle to interesting finishes. The rock is better than it looks as we removed the bad rock. There may still be some crispy/dirty holds. Be aware of the sun. In the summer sun, it can be extremely hot.

content.description:
This is a relatively new route at East Colfax.  It's worth posting some info in case beginners jump on it, because there are some loose things and you may want gear.  A bunch of folks were on it already, some pulling off blocks...and there is a scary block on the right.  Now, a first bolt has been added.

Climb from the right over a small bulge. Early on before the first bolt was placed, some started from the left on a ramp where one could get a yellow Alien in a left-facing flake.  Move up to a tiny overlap to the 1st bolt.  You can go left, over, or right of a small tree.  Continue up a slab passing a few bolts.  You can get a large purple Alien (~#0.75 or #1 Camalot size) before tiny runout to the last bolt.  Beware of a large, loose block on the right between the 2nd-to-last and last bolt.  Staying left is safer.  Clip the 2 bolt anchor with chains.

Per

Greg Hand

: the first 4 bolts were placed, and then they ran out of battery power.  The cleaning is in progress.  The plan is to extend it past the roof.
content.protection: 5 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with chains.  One can use a yellow Alien for the left start and a large purple Alien (#0.75 or #1 Camalot) to supplement the bolts.
content.location:
This is between

For The Children

and

East Colfax

.

content.description: The name says it all. Start right off the road bed. Move slightly right at the 2nd bolt.
content.location:
It is 30 feet left of the start of

East Colfax

.

content.description: This is steeper and more difficult than the slab routes to the right. Climb through 3 overhangs on big holds. It might be the best route on the cliff. This required removal of several loose blocks.
content.protection: 9 bolts to 2-bolt chains. Use a full length runner on the 2nd bolt to reduce drag.
content.location:
Between

East Colfax

&

Steve's Wild Turkey Day

, start as for

East Colfax

on the right side of the easy gully.

content.description: East Colfax starts out with some easy climbing that leads to a small, overhanging crux section, continues on some easier terrain that leads to more balanced climbing, and finishes on some beautiful sidepulls over a small roof to get to the anchors. If you diverge from the route, you may encounter not so good rock.
Small holds and hard moves lead through the initial roof (crux). Follow bolts above on steep rock with some big holds.
content.protection:
The first two bolts have been installed.

Bolts and Mussy hooks.
content.location:
It is 30 feet right of

The Good Earth

at a flared dihedral.

content.description:
Climb the intimidating looking, overhanging dihedral on big holds with the crux at the 4th bolt. Easy climbing leads left to a slabby finish. An alternate finish at a similar grade (First Planet) can be found by climbing to the right to finish on

Planet Earth

. This is quite good.
content.location:
Begin 20 feet right of

Heaven & Earth

at a left-facing dihedral.

climbs.name: Aurora Sports Park
climbs.fa: PH, Greg Hand, Richard Burrows, Brian Parsons, 7/29/2014

content.description:
Aurora Sports Park would have to be located on East Colfax.

Climb the steep, overhanging wall above

For the Grandchildren

. It has a powerful move at the lip. Disregard the Xs on the rock near the top. They are solid and do not need to be used anyway.
content.location:
This is an extension above

For the Grandchildren

.

content.description: Another boulder problem start leads to easier climbing above.
content.location:
Begin 15 feet right of

Planet Earth

.

content.description:
This is the continuation of

One for All

. The obvious large roof had to be climbed. You will probably not clip the 4th bolt on the lead, but it will help for working the route. Please feel free to give a rating as it has some cryptic moves.
content.protection:
6 more bolts to the anchors of

Just a Smidgen Harder

.
content.location:
It is above the anchors of

One for All

.

content.description:
This was drilled on my 64th birthday.

Climb steep looking (but moderate) rock joining

When I'm 64

at its last bolt.
content.location:
Begin 15 feet left of

Hunting Party

.
